entry.title: Combined summary - Request For Discussion / BIP number - Multi-Currency Hierarchy For Use In Multisignature Deterministic Wallets
entry.summary: Several email exchanges have been presented discussing various proposals for multi-signature wallets and hierarchical structures for multi-currency wallets based on multisig. One potential Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) called "Multi-Currency Hierarchy For Use In Multisignature Deterministic Wallets" has been submitted for discussion, seeking to create a new hierarchical structure for multi-currency wallets based on multisig. The proposal includes a "cosigner_index" branch similar to BIP-0045 to solve privacy problems in cases where parties cannot communicate.William from Airbitz discusses the scheme proposed by Alan for multi-signature wallets, asking about the motivation behind flattening the hierarchy in Alan's scheme. William suggests that their ideal structure would be BIP44 plus some no-collision logic. Alan responds by stating that he had originally proposed a "no-collision" scheme for multi-signature wallets, which doesn't require modifying the key tree structure at all, except for adding new internal and external chains.One respondent believed that the multi-currency hierarchy proposal was a good fit for multi-currency wallets based on multisig. However, they did not believe this was a BIP thing because it is improving altcoin usability. Another respondent shared the same sentiment and added that there is nothing in the spec that addresses the multisignature use-case. In contrast, another respondent suggested that the existing BIP 44 hierarchy should be used instead, adding the convention that "wallet/account N" is the same wallet in each supported currency.Overall, these email exchanges revolve around proposing and refining hierarchical structures for multi-currency and multi-signature wallets, with discussions and critiques of different proposals and suggestions for improvement. The proposal seeks to address the issue of supporting multiple currencies in a single wallet. Swanson questions the uniqueness of the proposal as it seems quite similar to BIP 44 but with fields arranged differently. Supporters argue that the proposal is practical and already has a working reference implementation with no reason not to assign a BIP number.In an email exchange, Kefkius requested further discussion on the topic and provided a link to the proposal on Github. The proposal seeks to limit the possible implementations of multi-currency, multisignature wallets and enable the generation of litecoin or darkcoin multisigs without permission. The proposal suggests sticking coin type on the public derivation side of things so that a user can generate any desired currency of a wallet without requiring n xpubs where n is the number of currencies shared.Alan proposed a "no-collision" scheme for multi-signature wallets, which does not require modifying the key tree structure. The proposal addresses a current issue in the cryptocurrency community and proposes a potential solution that could offer increased security and flexibility for users who hold multiple currencies in a single wallet. The author acknowledges that there may be challenges in implementing this system, but believes that it could have significant benefits for the cryptocurrency community. Overall, the author is seeking feedback and discussion on their proposal, as well as consideration for assigning a BIP number.
